According to her plea deal, Kendra Licari is not able to see her daughter. In the doc, Lauryn Licari says she wants to see her mom “when the time is right.”

“I think I want to trust her now, but I don’t think I can,” Lauryn Licari says. “Now that she’s out, I just want her to get the help she needs so then when we see each other, it doesn’t go back to the old ways and how it was before.”
TODAY.com has reached out to Kendra Licari for comment and has not heard back by the time of publication.

title: Bad Bunny Opens Up About the ‘Emotional’ Song That Made His Mom Cry
summary: Bad Bunny reveals the emotional story behind his song “La Mudanza,” which brought his mother to tears.
story: Bad Bunny is sharing a song that hit an emotional chord for his mother.
During an interview with "NBC Nightly News" anchor Tom Llamas, the superstar, whose given name is Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, shared how his mom teared up while listening to “La Mudanza.”
When asked why the song made his mom, Lysaurie Ocasio, cry, the artist explained the personal connection.
“Because I’m just telling the story about how my parents meet each other, and how I came to this world,” Bad Bunny shared. “So it’s a very special story and it’s a very emotional song.”
"La Mudanza" is featured on Bad Bunny's sixth studio album, “Debí Tirar Más Fotos,” which translates to “I should’ve taken more photos,” and was released in January.
The deeply personal, genre-blending LP is a love letter to Puerto Rico and family, and quickly became a chart-topper.

“I always wanted to make a salsa album,” he said, adding that he always thought it would be a project he did when he was older “when I turn 40 or something like that.” “And when I started to work on this album it was organically, everything. Like, “DTMF” song, the way that we created that song, it was- all just happening at the moment, feelings, people that (were) in the studio. You know, ‘Come here, let’s sing together.’”
Adding to his spotlight on his beloved culture and heritage, Bad Bunny kicked off a 30-show residency in his native Puerto Rico.

“It’s the best experience that I ever had in my life, in my career,” he said. “It’s more than a show. It’s more than a concert. It’s the culture right there, people all love each other, singing together. It’s something magical.”
You can see more of Bad Bunny during his full interview sit-down with Willie Geist on this weekend’s "Sunday TODAY."

title: Liam Payne's Girlfriend Shares Tribute on What Would Have Been His 32nd Birthday
summary: Kate Cassidy, the girlfriend of Liam Payne, paid an emotional tribute to the late singer to honor what would have been his 32nd birthday.
story: Kate Cassidy, the girlfriend of Liam Payne, paid an emotional tribute to the late singer to honor what would have been his 32nd birthday.

Cassidy shared a carousel of pics of her and the former One Direction member Aug. 29 on Instagram. "My dearest Liam, It breaks my heart being that I can’t hand you a physical birthday card today. That I can’t hear your laugh, or tell you all the things I wish I’d said a thousand more times," she wrote in her caption.
Cassidy went on to say she had been, "struggling to find the right words" before wishing him a  happy birthday.

"Today you would have been 32. In your 31 years here on this earth you brought so much joy, happiness and hope to so many — especially to me. I hope you know how brightly you still shine, even from up there," she wrote.
“I would give up years of my life just to give you a few more,” Cassidy continued, adding that she missed “making memories” and “having things to look forward to" with Payne.

"But today, my birthday gift to you is my strength. I promise you I will celebrate you extra today, honor your life, and cherish the beautiful times we’ve had. August 29th will be a date that sits in my heart for the rest of my life. I love you so much," she concluded.
Payne died in October 2024 after falling from a balcony on the third floor of a hotel in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Prior to his tragic death, Payne filmed his final television appearance for the new Netflix singing competition “Building the Band."
The show, which premiered on July 9 and is hosted by former Backstreet Boy AJ McLean, features Payne serving as a judge Payne alongside Nicole Scherzinger and Kelly Rowland.
Speaking to TODAY.com in July, McLean remembered Payne as “the coolest dude."

“Whether it was a dressing room, on set, where he was, he lit up that space with his energy, with his open heart, open mind. He was extremely, very well spoken, very articulate when it came to giving feedback as a mentor to these groups," McLean said of his fellow former boy bander.
During a "Sunday Sitdown" with Willie Geist the same month,  Scherzinger said Payne was a "dear friend" to her.

“I put One Direction together, so it’s come full circle for us,” said the Tony winner, referring to her role in the formation of the popular boy band, which counted Payne, Harry Styles, Zayn Malik, Niall Horan and Louis Tomlinson as its members, during her time as a judge on “The X Factor.”
"Building the Band" was a "full circle" moment for Payne, who was able to give the show's aspiring artists "really good advice, thanks to his own success, said Scherzinger.
"Liam just shines in the show,” she said. “He’s just a natural beautiful bright light. Anyone who knows him — he has a very kind, giving heart. And he gets to, you know, give back.”

title: Queen Latifah's Lookalike Son Rebel Makes Rare Appearance With Mom at WNBA Game
summary: Queen Latifah made a rare appearance with her young son, Rebel, at a New York Liberty basketball game in Brooklyn, New York.
story: Queen Latifah made a rare appearance with her young son, Rebel.
On Aug. 25, the pair stepped out in Brooklyn, New York, to see the Connecticut Sun take on the New York Liberty at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York.
On the court, Queen Latifah and her kid were seen posing for pictures next to players, including Olivia Nelson-Ododa, Aaliyah Edwards and Bria Hartley from the Connecticut Sun.
They were also seen taking a picture with New York Liberty player Jonquel Jones.
For the special outing, Rebel wore an aqua and black colored jersey with a pair of cargo pants and Laitfah donned what appeared to be a silk shirt with some blue jeans, white sneakers and a hat.

The "Living Single" star is a proud mom of one and she shares Rebel with her partner, Eboni Nichols. In 2021, she gave her kiddo a shout-out when she was being honored with the lifetime achievement award at the 2021 BET Awards.

During her closing remarks, she said, "I’m going to get off this stage, but I thank you so much for all of you, the fans for supporting every crazy-a-- thing I’ve done through the years. And thank you for making 'Equalizer' No. 1. Eboni, my love. Rebel, my love. Peace — Happy Pride!”
In 2017, Queen Latifah spoke to People about parenthood and said she always envisioned her with a "big family."

"I’m a late bloomer. I’m a late bloomer with a lot of things and you know — nobody’s perfect. I’m an overachiever in some ways and just like slow as molasses in other ways," she said. "I think I kind of needed to grow and mature and get everything kind of taken care of with everything before I was able to really deal with it."
The "U.N.I.T.Y." rapper also opened up about adoption and said that's always something that's caught her eye.
"I definitely want to adopt," she said.
Queen Latifah added that it didn't matter how old the child was -- she just wanted to be there to give them a sense of family.

"To me, it's the most unselfish thing you could do, to be a parent. It's not about you at all. It's about what you can give to support this child growing into adulthood. And so it doesn't matter if it's a baby or a toddler or a teenager, for that matter," she said. "As long as they get to feel like they have a mother, they have a home, they have a family and somebody who's there for them."

title: ‘Hunting Wives’ Creator Rebecca Cutter Reacts to ‘Great’ Fan Theory About Margo, Sophie and Murder
summary: "The Hunting Wives" showrunner Rebecca Cutter talks to TODAY.com about the Netflix show's Margo (Malin Akerman) and Sophie (Brittany Snow) romance and foreshadowing.
story: Warning: This story contains spoilers from “The Hunting Wives” book and television series.

You won’t find a bigger fan of “The Hunting Wives” than its creator, Rebecca Cutter. The self-professed “Margo truther” is basking in “incredible gratitude” after such massive fan reaction to the Netflix hit, which continues to be the most-watched streaming original show this month.

The series, originally made for Starz before finding its home at Netflix, has been a mainstay in the streamer’s Top 10 list in the U.S. since its July release. It has become the subject of multiple group chats and fan edits on social media, and a new ship has set sail as a result of the eight-episode season: Margo (Malin Åkerman) and Sophie (Brittany Snow). The Instagram account for “The Hunting Wives” even posted a callout for viewers to cast their vote for what their couple name should be.
“I had a lot of confidence in what the show was,” Cutter tells TODAY.com, adding if Netflix could bring in the viewership, “I know I can keep them watching the show.”
“I started to let myself be hopeful,” she continues, “but I still could have never predicted the wide range of people that seem to love the show. That’s shocking to me.”

“The Hunting Wives,” which is an adaptation of author May Cobb’s novel, follows Sophie O’Neil and her husband, Graham O’Neil (Evan Jonigkeit), as they move with their son from the Northeast to a small town in east Texas. She falls in with a group of Southern female socialites, which includes queen bee Margo Banks, who happens to be married to Graham’s hotshot new boss, Jed Banks (Dermot Mulroney), an aspiring politician. The group’s idea of a good time includes going boar hunting, a lot of drinking and for some, even hooking up with one another. It doesn’t take long for Sophie to fall under Margo’s spell, and the two meet up for secret romantic rendezvouses. At the same time, they’re grappling with the latest drama to hit the small town: the murder of teenager Abby Jackson.

In twists that deviate from the book, Margo ends up being Abby’s killer — not Jill (Katie Lowes), one of the moms in the girls group whose 18-year-old son, Brad, is also secretly hooking up with Margo. And, Margo does not die in the TV adaptation, but she does at the end of the book.
Cutter says she knew “well before” Åkerman was cast as Margo that she wanted Margo as the killer in the show.
“That was one of the first things when I read the book that I knew would be one of the big changes,” she explains. “I knew I wanted her to do it, and I knew I wanted her to stay alive.”

She also crafted a grittier personal backstory for her Margo, which includes a complicated relationship with brother Kyle. Cutter says her “main intention” with the changes she made was to “give everybody more sort of character work to do.”

“I also just wanted to open up a different part of Texas,” Cutter says. “It is fun to watch rich people, but it’s also interesting to open up a different world and to have a real divide of the classes.”
She adds that she loves the scene of Sophie showing up at a trailer park to visit a naked Kyle during his “meth bender.”
“It opens up the world and opens up plot possibilities,” she says.
After reading the book, Cutter traveled to Longview, Texas, about two hours east of Dallas, to do research, and not only met Cobb, but Cobb's high school best friend.
“Within 10 minutes, it was totally the ‘I love you’ scene (in the show with Margo and Sophie),” she says.
She says they went on a three-day trip and shot guns, ate barbecue and went to honky-tonks.
“It was just a blast, and we talk, like, three times a week now,” Cutter says.
Cobb previously told TODAY.com she feels that Cutter “took the spirit of the book, of these rowdy, sassy — to put it mildly — Texas women, and just turned it up to an 11.”
She added that Cutter made the show “even more unapologetic and juicy and bonkers than the book.”

“Really blowing out the different storylines and adding in some new characters and giving existing characters different backstories,” Cobb said. “It's escapist fun at a time when I feel like people are really looking for that.”
About That Margo, Sophie, Abby Fan Theory

When Margo and Sophie first meet at an NRA party at Margo and Jed's house, Sophie offers Margo a Xanax. Later on, Sophie and Margo again take Sophie's Xanax before embarking on a blackout bender the night Abby is murdered.
Cutter says she didn’t really think of the Xanax connection as an Easter egg but more of a plot device for the blackout and to “very specifically” establish Sophie’s state of mind.
“I try and always be as character-motivated as possible and not so much for foreshadowing, but I’m glad it worked out,” she says.

What could possibly be foreshadowing, however, is the boar hunting outing that the wives embark on. Sophie, new to shooting, takes down a boar — but doesn’t kill it. Callie (Jaime Ray Newman), who also happens to be the sheriff’s wife, delivers the fatal shot to put the boar out of its misery.

As the series progresses, Sophie becomes the prime suspect in Abby’s murder because her gun is the one used to kill Abby, and surveillance footage in the woods shows Abby and Sophie interacting the night Abby was killed. The show actually begins with a scene of a wounded woman, who viewers later learn is Abby, running in the woods shouting for help while she's being shot at. Sophie can’t remember the events of the night because she was blacked out. After various other clues arise in the case, police presume Jill is the killer, and Sophie is seemingly free.
Sophie, however, pieces together that Margo is actually the killer and confronts her friend turned lover, who begs her not to tell, saying she loves her and “fixed it.”

One fan theory states that Sophie actually fired the initial shots at Abby, but she didn’t kill her — just like the boar — and Margo stepped in to deliver the kill shot to protect both Sophie and herself. Margo just never told Sophie about those initial shots, possibly to protect Sophie, who expressed guilt to Margo over a previous accident in the Northeast when she hit and killed a pedestrian while drinking and driving, according to the fan theory.
“It’s a great theory,” Cutter says. “I don’t want to confirm or deny because who knows what will come out in future seasons.”
The Margo and Sophie of It All
Before Sophie, Margo was in a secret romantic relationship on the side with Callie. But once Sophie comes to town, she becomes her focus, and Margo dumps Callie.
Margo tells Sophie, “There’s something about me that wants to protect you,” and by contrast, later says to Callie, “I’m Margo f------ Banks. I don’t need protection.”
Was this moment with Sophie a genuine one for Margo, and she was actually looking out for someone who wasn’t herself?

“I always feel like with Margo — and actually I feel this way about humans in general — this is how I like to write characters. Everything can be both things at once,” Cutter says. “You can be a manipulator but also mean it. So I do think she feels that way about Sophie, and I think that’s one of the beautiful things about Brittany Snow’s performance, is that everyone, I think, kind of feels like, ‘I wish I could just wrap this girl up in a blanket because she’s causing herself a lot of trouble.’
“And I think Margo definitely feels protective of her and loving of her, and it doesn’t mean that it’s all out of the goodness of her heart either. She obviously had ulterior motives.”
Cutter adds she believes the “richest characters” are “sort of femme fatale.”
“It’s not fun if they’re just completely calculated monsters, but it’s not fun if they don’t have any evil intent, either,” she explains. “There should always be multiple layers going on.”
Cobb said the Margo-Sophie dynamic in the show is similar to the book with “Sophie falling under her spell.”

“I do think Margo has feelings for her, but Margo is a more transactional person and manipulator,” she said. “I think she genuinely cares for Sophie, but, you know, watch out if, oh, I just can't wait. I hope there's a Season 2 so we can find out what's going to happen.” (The show has not yet been officially picked up for Season 2.)
There are, of course, Margo and Sophie fans who want the pairing to be the endgame, while others don’t think they’d make it in the long run because Margo can be so toxic and self-serving.

“I just love Margo even — I love her either way,” Cutter says. “I’m, like, a Margo truther. I don’t care if she’s evil. I don’t care if she was completely justified. I like her. I’m going to watch her either way. I’m going to sleep with her.

“It’s funny, people want to really have it defined, and they want to have it defined by me. And I always say, like, ‘Babe, make your own decision. I don’t own the character. If you want to think that she’s telling the truth, believe that. If you don’t, it should work either way.’”

(For the record, Cutter is a fan of the first wig Margo wears in the show, before going blond as Jed’s campaign for governor gets underway. “I’m shocked that everyone hates it so much. I think she’s iconic. … It looks fantastic on her and established her character.”)
Her Favorite Margo and Sophie Scene

Cutter says the Margo and Sophie scene she loves the most is from the first episode, when Margo brings Sophie home following an intimate detour in a parking lot after a night out at the bar with the girls.

“I love the moment when Margo’s dropping her off in that first episode, and she’s like, ‘Oh, we’re going to have so much fun together. I love you.’ And Sophie goes, ‘I love you, too.’ It was exactly how I pictured it when I wrote it, which is that thing of … women do this all the time. We make fast friends, and we say, ‘I love you,’ not meaning it, exactly. … But then Sophie saying it in a different way. Obviously, she’s not in love with her yet, but Brittany is putting all those levels into it where you’re like, ‘Wait, does she love her love her?’ She’s not just saying it back in the same tone that Margo was saying it. That’s for sure.”
Cutter says she’s seen the episode “hundreds of times in the editing room.”
“Erwin Stoff, who’s the other executive producer, every time he knew that it would make me smile,” she says of the scene. “So he would always look over and wait for me to be smiling at that take.”
Is Sophie in Love With Margo?
Snow said she played the character of Sophie like she was in love with Margo.
“I don’t like to speak for our fictional characters, even though I did write them,” Cutter says. “I certainly think she was falling in love with her.”
While the reveal of Margo as Abby’s murderer “complicates things,” Cutter says, “It becomes a question of, like, ‘Can you love someone knowing how deeply flawed they are?’”
That’s something that will have to be addressed in the future, as will the fallout of Sophie killing Margo’s brother in the show’s final moments of the first season.
Will Margo ever be able to forgive Sophie? “We’ll have to see,” Cutter teases.

One thing that is for certain is that Sophie has “been in denial” about her sexuality. A flashback reveals Sophie and her female college roommate crossed the friendship line and spent a romantic night together.

“I think that was important to me to show that it wasn’t just — Margo is magical, even though she is, but, like, I mean she’s magical to bring her out of it, but I did want to give Sophie more of a thorough queerness … a richer sense that it isn’t just, ‘Oh, Margo’s this unicorn,’ but that this is something Sophie has thought and felt before and been in denial about or pushing away. And that Margo is the one that’s able to make it seem like a feasible life choice.”
Cobb said it was “super smart” for Cutter to give Sophie “a more compelling background.”
“She's falling head over heels for Margo,” Cobb said of Sophie, “and it's an unstoppable force.”

“In the book, she doesn't have that backstory, and then Graham's need to sort of control her,” she continued. “I think there's a tension there of, ‘Wow, there's absolutely nothing wrong with my home life. Husband's great, treats me great. And yet I cannot resist the siren call of Margo Banks.’”
The show has led many people to share their thoughts online about how the show has made them rethink sexuality.
Cutter says it’s “so rewarding” to see her work be that “closely watched and processed.”

“You spend all this time writing something, and you don’t know — people could just be there texting or doing their laundry or yelling at their kids and barely watching it,” she says. “So to have people, like, making edits and really parsing out, like, ‘What did that line mean?’ or ‘What was that look?’ or ‘Look at what her hand does there.’
“It’s just like, oh my God, you feel so seen. And I’m so grateful that people are feeling seen by this show. I love that it’s a two-way street.”

title: Does Jackie Choose Cole or Alex in 'My Life With the Walter Boys' Season 2?
summary: Does Jackie Howard end up with Cole or Alex at the end of My LIfe with the Walter Boys Season 2?
story: Jackie Howard’s love life ended on a cliffhanger at the end of Season 1 of “My Life with the Walter Boys.”

The Netflix series follows a Manhattan teen who moves to Colorado after losing her family. She now lives with her late mom’s best friend and her many (many) kids — eight, plus two cousins living with the family.

Jackie has a “thing” with two of the Walter boys: Younger brother Alex (Ashby Gentry) and older brother Cole (Noah Lalonde). She dates Alex in Season 1 — then kisses Cole in the finale. It’s enough to send her running away for the summer back to New York.
Come Season 2, Jackie tells Alex that she and Cole had kissed. He's livid and confronts his brother, who tries to apologize. Alex doesn't accept the apology.

But it doesn't take long for Alex to decide that he can't get over Jackie and, despite some other flirtations, they get back together. Still, Cole and Jackie share a few longing glances, indicating things aren't quite over between them.

“This season, Jackie’s ready to face everything a little bit more head on. Season 1, she pushes everything away and runs away from her problems. And I think Season 2, she’s trying not to do that,” Nikki Rodriguez, who plays Jackie, tells TODAY.com.
Read on to find out how things end up between Jackie and the Walter boys.
Who does Jackie end up with in the end of ‘My Life with the Walter Boys’ Season 2?
Season 2 ends with Jackie at a crossroads between both Cole and Alex, and possibly about to lose them both.
Earlier on in the episode, Cole stumbles on Alex and Jackie kissing and seems upset. He confronts Jackie about getting back together with Alex.
“I was giving you space, like you asked. But I thought we had something. So I’ve been wracking my brain trying to figure out why you’d be with my brother — again,” Cole says.
“We said that we were going to be friends,” Jackie says.
“We’ve never just been friends,” Cole says.
Jackie says she “can’t be” with someone who makes her feel the way Cole does. It’s then that Cole declares he loves Jackie. She admits she loves him too.
“Why would being with me be so awful?” he asks.
She indicates it has something to do with her history and the trauma of losing her family. Cole makes her feel out of control _ and she can't have that.
“When we kissed, it was the only time I ever stopped thinking about everything … I felt very free, like I was out of control. And I can’t have that. I can’t lose control,” she says.
Then — surprise, surprise — Alex reveals that he’s heard the entire conversation.
What do the actors think will come next?
Speaking to TODAY.com, Rodriguez addressed the question of “Cole or Alex” head-on.
“I get this question a lot, and I always say ‘Team Jackie.’ I mean it — I think that I think Jackie should follow her heart wherever that leads her to,” she says.

Rodriguez says Jackie is afraid to make a decision. “Jackie ultimately doesn’t want to hurt anybody, and she doesn’t want to make any mistakes. She tries to be this perfect version of herself all the time,” she says.
Meanwhile, after a season with Jackie, Noah Lalonde says Cole has made a decision about Jackie.

“When Jackie enters Cole’s life, he’s in a vulnerable position. Then here comes Jackie, having just lost her family and having somehow gotten back up. She serves as an inspiration to him … and as that develops, I think he realizes that she’s just the type of person you’d want to spend your life with,” Lalonde says.

Alex, meanwhile, is experiencing deja vu — he has been in this position before. In Season 1, we learn that Cole had hooked up with a girl Alex was seeing. Cole later says he didn’t know her connection to his brother.
When asked for his reaction to the declaration of love, Gentry says, “He’s probably thinking, ‘Bruh, again?’ I think he is just confused. So hopefully he’ll get some answers.”
Read a full recap of "My Life with the Walter Boys" Season 2's ending.

title: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce Attend Football Game at His Alma Mater in 1st Appearance After Engagement
summary: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce made their first public appearance together after getting engaged at Arrowhead Stadium, where the University of Nebraska’s Cornhuskers took on the University of Cincinnati’s Bearcats, Kelce’s alma mater.
story: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce made their first public appearance together as an engaged couple.

On Aug. 28, the duo was seen watching the University of Nebraska’s Cornhuskers take on the University of Cincinnati’s Bearcats, Kelce’s alma mater, at Arrowhead Stadium. The Nebraska Cornhuskers beat the Cincinnati Bearcats 20-17.

Swift and Kelce were seen watching the game alongside Kelce's brother, Jason Kelce. Patrick and Brittany Mahomes were also spotted that night, with Swift and Brittany Mahomes seen walking through the stadium together at one point.

Kelce wore a hat that said "Bearcats" on the front, a sweet homage to his college days when he used to play for the Cincinnati team.The Kansas City Chiefs tight end attended the school from 2008 to 2012, per the University of Cincinnati's website, before he was drafted by the Kansas City Chiefs in 2013.

As for Swift, she donned a sleeveless white sweater, grey mini skirt and a pair of nude-colored boots for the outing. The "Life of a Showgirl" singer was also seen flashing her new diamond ring as she drank from a cup.
On Aug. 26, Taylor Swift announced she and Kelce had gotten engaged after sharing pictures of Kelce's garden proposal on Instagram.
In one of the snaps, Swift showed off her engagement ring, which is an old mine diamond by Kindred Lubeck of Artifex Fine Jewelry.
The "Karma" singer wrote in the caption, "Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married 🧨."

While the couple themselves haven't weighed in on specific details around the proposal just yet, Travis Kelce's dad, Ed, said that pair got engaged at a garden in Lee’s Summit, Missouri, about two weeks before they shared the news on Instagram.

“He got her out there, they were about to go out to dinner, and he said, ‘Let’s go out and have a glass of wine,’ ... they got out there, and that’s when he asked her, and it was beautiful,” Ed Kelce told ABC News 5 Cleveland. “They started FaceTiming me and their mother and her folks to make sure everybody knew. So, to see them together is great.”

title: See Which Stars From ‘The Office’ Reunited at a Party for the Show’s Spinoff, ‘The Paper’
summary: Ellie Kemper, Oscar Nuñez, Kate Flannery, Creed Bratton and Paul Lieberstein posed together for a photo at an after-party for a premiere of Peacock's "The Paper."
story: Once a Dunder Mifflin employee, always a Dunder Mifflin employee.
Several stars of the original NBC series “The Office” turned out Aug. 27 in Los Angeles to celebrate the show’s highly anticipated spinoff, “The Paper,” which drops Sept. 4 on Peacock.
(Peacock is part of our parent company, NBCUniversal.)
Ellie Kemper, Oscar Nuñez, Kate Flannery, Creed Bratton and Paul Lieberstein all posed for a photo together during an after-party.

Nuñez, who played levelheaded accountant Oscar Martínez in “The Office,” will appear in “The Paper,” which takes place in the same universe as “The Office.” The show will revolve around a newspaper in Toledo, Ohio, trying to stay afloat.
Kemper, who joined “The Office” in Season 5 and is married to “The Paper” co-creator Michael Koman, is psyched for the new series.
“Mama’s NIGHT OUT!!!! An absolutely iconic evening celebrating the premiere of #ThePaper with friends old and also new,” she captioned a photo of her and her husband on Instagram at the premiere.

“This show is just fantastic. Where do I begin?? Created by the incomparable #GregDaniels and the fun-loving @michael.koman (also my husband) and starring a cast of actors that you cannot believe you get to watch all in one show,” she added.
“The Paper” stars Domhnall Gleeson, Sabrina Impacciatore, Chelsea Frei, Melvin Gregg, Gbemisola Ikumelo and Alex Edelman.
“The Office” ran for nine seasons from 2005 until 2013 and still remains popular to this day.

“The show feels bigger over the last five years than it ever did when it was on the air,” star Brian Baumgartner told TODAY in April when he sat down for an interview with fellow castmates Nuñez, Kemper, Flannery, Bratton, Leslie David Baker and Angela Kinsey in honor of the 20th anniversary of the series’s premiere.
“I think the end of the legacy has not fully been written yet.”

title: The True Story Behind 'Unknown Number': Who Was Sending the Texts?
summary: What is the true story of Unknown Number? What happened to Kendra and Lauryn Licari? Who was sending the catfishing text messages?
story: This story discusses suicide. If you or someone you know is struggling or in crisis, help is available. Call or text 988 or chat at 988lifeline.org.
In September 2021, high school student Lauryn Licari and her boyfriend began receiving cruel text messages from an unknown number.

The anonymous notes turned darker and more harassing, according to a new Netflix documentary about the case, “Unknown Number: The High School Catfish.” The documentary includes interviews with Lauryn Licari’s parents, local law enforcement and FBI officials who eventually got involved in the case.
Even after a group of parents, school officials and the town police got involved, the sender’s identity remained a mystery.
In the meantime, Lauryn Licari’s mom, Kendra Licari, told her daughter not to let the messages consume her.

“I was just getting super frustrated with it but my mom was like, ‘Just ignore them. Obviously you’re beautiful.’ Like, she was just encouraging me to not read them,” Lauryn Licari says in the documentary.
“I told her just to keep being her and just not even worry about anything, right?”Kendra Licari says in the doc. “I didn’t believe anybody would do anything harmful.”
When the sender’s identity was finally uncovered, it shocked everyone in their tight-knit community.

Director Skye Borgman tells TODAY.com that while her film highlights one “extreme case” of online abuse, the documentary demonstrates more widely “the massive impact cyberbullying has on students, on young people, on friends and families, on parents.”
Read on to learn more about the case.
Who was sending the text messages?
The cyberbully turned out to be Lauryn Licari’s mom, Kendra Licari.

In December 2022, Kendra Licari was charged with two counts of stalking a minor, two counts of communicating with another to commit a crime and one count of obstruction of justice, per an Isabella County arrest warrant obtained by TODAY.com.
Licari pleaded guilty to two counts of stalking a minor in March 2023, and the other charges were dismissed, per an Isabella County sentencing document obtained by TODAY.com

She was sentenced in April 2023 on two counts of stalking a minor, per the sentencing document. She was sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison, with a minimum sentence of one year and seven months, per the sentencing document.
What have Lauryn and Kendra Licari said about what happened?
Kendra Licari has expressed remorse about what happened.

“I never want to hurt anyone else like I have already done,” she said in a tearful courtroom address before her sentencing. “I actually look forward to continuing my work and continuing my progress daily. I have caused a lot of damage to my family.”
Kendra Licari also participated in the documentary, sitting down for an interview a few months after she was released from prison in 2024.
In the documentary, Kendra Licari says she is “very disappointed” in herself, and says she let herself and her family down.
Director Borgman says she was “deeply curious” about Kendra Licari, and says she believes her perspective adds to the complexity of the story.

“If she hadn’t been part of the documentary, I think audiences could have written her off a little bit more,” Borgman tells TODAY.com. “And look, they may do that now, but at least they have the opportunity to think about her and to think about what she’s been through.”
That said, Borgman believes Kendra Licari is an unreliable narrator.

“I think her memories have sort of changed her version of the truth,” Borgman says. “I think she’s got a little bit of revisionist history. I think some of what she says is the truth. I think some of what she says isn’t truthful, where those two intersect is constantly changing.”

Borgman also says Kendra Licari’s answers sometimes seemed “a little bit rehearsed” when she was challenged on her version of events in her interview. For example, Kendra Licari says that she didn’t send the first threatening messages, but rather jumped in later to try and root out the perpetrator.

Lauryn Licari also opens up in the documentary about her complicated relationship with her mom. On the one hand, she says she has lost trust in her mother, but on the other hand, she still misses having her mom around.
“Being without that relationship I think is really hurting me, and I think rebuilding our relationship will help both of us a lot,” Lauryn Licari says in the doc. “I love her more than anything.”
Where are they now?
Kendra Licari was released on parole on Aug. 8, 2024, and will be supervised as a parolee until February 2026, according to her inmate record from the Michigan Department of Corrections.
As part of the conditions of her supervised release, she is not allowed to leave the state and must “make earnest efforts to find and maintain employment,” according to her inmate record.
She is also not allowed to see her daughter, per agreements from her plea deal.
At the time she was interviewed for the documentary, Kendra Licari said it had been about a year-and-a-half since she had seen her daughter.
In the doc, Lauryn Licari says she wants to see her mom “when the time is right.”

“I think I want to trust her now, but I don’t think I can,” Lauryn Licari says. “Now that she’s out, I just want her to get the help she needs so then when we see each other, it doesn’t go back to the old ways and how it was before.”
Kendra Licari says she believes she and her daughter can still have a healthy relationship.
“We both know that we’re with each other, no matter what,” she says in the doc.
Meanwhile, Lauryn Licari finished high school this year and is “ready to enter ... the next phase of her life,” Borgman tells TODAY.com.
According to an update at the end of the film, Lauryn Licari is planning on attending college to study criminology.
Borgman says participating in the documentary was a “big deal” for Lauryn Licari, who wanted to reclaim agency in the telling of her story.
As for what Lauryn and Kendra Licari's relationship might look like going forward? Borgman says that’s “a question for Lauryn.”

“She’s an adult now, and she gets to make the decision and she gets to decide if she wants to have a relationship with her mom,” Borgman says. “She gets to decide what her future holds. And I think it’s a really great place for her to be.”

title: Watch Role Model Serenade Al Roker As 'Sally' During TODAY's Citi Concert Series
summary: During Role Model's Citi Concert Series on TODAY, he brought out Al Roker on stage as his latest "Sally," adding to the extensive list of celebrities who have had the honor.
story: Al Roker got his morning boogie on thanks to Role Model.
On Aug. 29, the 28-year-old singer performed his Citi Concert Series on TODAY, where he belted out several of his hits, including “Sally, When the Wine Runs Out.”
The song has become a staple at Role Model's concerts, and per tradition, the Maine native brings up a fan on stage and dubs them “Sally” to dance along with him.
Role Model, whose real name is Tucker Pillsbury, did just that during his time on the TODAY Plaza. When it was time to pick a Sally, he had none other than Al join him.
"Where's my Sally tonight?" Role Model asked, which is when the TODAY weatherman emerged.
Al rocked a cowboy hat and a wine glass in his hand as he walked onto the stage, smiling from ear to ear while singing along to the lyrics.
"Sally, everybody!" Role Model said of Al as the song wrapped.
Al joins a star-studded club of "Sallys" who've joined Role Model on stage during the song, including Jake Shane, Kate Hudson, Natalie Portman and Reneé Rapp.

Role Model released a deluxe version of his album, “Kansas Anymore," in February and wrapped his "No Place Like Tour" in April. His acting star is also rising, as it was announced in May that he'll be joining a star-studded cast of Lena Dunham's comedy feature "Good Sex."
Role Model previously talked to TODAY.com about how he handles his newfound fame after the success of his album and sold-out tour.

“I try not to think about it too much. I stick to my little daily routine,” he said in April. “But it is very cool that people are coming to shows and enjoying the album and that’s all you can ask for.”

title: WWE's Clash in Paris Airs Sunday. Here Are the Matches and How to Watch
summary: WWE's Clash in Paris 2025 PLE will take place Sunday, Aug. 31. Here's the start time, the matches on the card and how to watch and stream the event.
story: John Cena’s farewell tour with WWE continues this weekend in Paris.

The actor and wrestling legend, who will wrap up his WWE career in December, will step into the ring to face Logan Paul at Clash in Paris on Sunday, Aug. 31. The show will mark WWE’s first premium live event in the City of Light.

It wasn’t too long ago that Cena and Paul were allies. They teamed up at Money in the Bank in June to face Cody Rhodes and Jey Uso. But it’s been a different Cena we’ve seen on TV lately, after he lost his Undisputed WWE Championship to Rhodes at SummerSlam and moved on from the heel turn that shocked fans earlier this year.
Here’s what to know ahead of Clash in Paris.
What Is the Start Time for WWE’s Clash in Paris?
It’s an early start time for American wrestling fans, given the time difference. Clash in Paris begins at 2 p.m. ET (8 p.m. Paris time) on Sunday, Aug. 31, at Paris La Défense Arena.
Which Matches Are on the Card for WWE’s Clash in Paris?
Here are the advertised matches for Clash in Paris, as of this writing:

World Heavyweight Champion Seth Rollins vs. CM Punk vs. Jey Uso vs. LA KnightJohn Cena vs. Logan PaulRoman Reigns vs. Bronson ReedSheamus vs. Rusev (Good Ol’ Fashioned Donnybrook Match)Women’s Intercontinental Champion Becky Lynch vs. Nikki Bella
World Heavyweight Champion Seth Rollins vs. CM Punk vs. Jey Uso vs. LA Knight
John Cena vs. Logan Paul
Roman Reigns vs. Bronson Reed
Sheamus vs. Rusev (Good Ol’ Fashioned Donnybrook Match)
Women’s Intercontinental Champion Becky Lynch vs. Nikki Bella
How Can I Watch WWE’s Clash in Paris?

Clash in Paris will stream live on Peacock in the U.S. and on Netflix in select international countries. The show will also be screened in select U.S. theaters nationwide. For more information and to buy tickets, visit Fandango’s website. (Peacock and Fandango are owned by TODAY.com’s parent company, NBCUniversal.)

title: Heidi Gardner Not Returning to 'Saturday Night Live' After 8 Seasons
summary: Heidi Gardner is leaving “Saturday Night Live” after eight seasons.
story: Heidi Gardner is leaving “Saturday Night Live” after eight seasons.
TODAY.com has learned that the comedian will not be returning to “SNL,” amid shakeups ahead of the comedy sketch show’s 51st season.
Gardner, who has yet to speak out on her departure, made her “SNL” debut during the show’s 43rd season in 2017.
Among her fan-favorite characters are “Angel, Every Boxer’s Girlfriend from Every Movie About Boxing Ever” and “Crystal, Your Co-Worker Who is Extremely Busy Doing Seemingly Nothing.”
Last year, she made headlines for breaking character during a “Beavis and Butt-Head” sketch with Mikey Day and Ryan Gosling.

Outside of “SNL,” Gardner, 42, has appeared in films such as “Hustle,” “Life of the Party” and “Trust Fall.” She also has a recurring role in the Apple TV+ series “Shrinking” and had minor roles in “You” and “Superstore.”
Gardner’s exit comes after “SNL” creator Lorne Michaels said in an August interview with Puck News that he had plans to “shake things up” for the new season.
Michaels, who has been running the show since its debut in 1975, noted that he felt “pressure to reinvent” after the historic 50th season.
Since then, many cast members and writers have started to announce that they were leaving “SNL.”
Devon Walker shared the news in an Instagram post he captioned, “me and baby broke up.”
Emil Wakim also announced the “gut punch” of not returning to “SNL” next year on Instagram. Michael Longfellow also shared on Aug. 28 that he would also not be returning for a fourth season.
As the cast gets finalized, expect more people to share if they are returning or leaving “SNL.”
Season 51 of “Saturday Night Live” will premiere Oct. 4 on NBC.

title: ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’ Season 3, Episode 8, Ends in Heartbreak. Read the Letter That Caused It All
summary: Season 3, Episode 8, of "TSITP" ends in heartbreak for Belly after her fiancé, Jeremiah, receives a letter from Susannah that was actually meant for his brother, Conrad.
story: Warning: Major spoilers ahead for the most recent episode of “The Summer I Turned Pretty” Season 3 ...
The most recent episode of the third and final season of “The Summer I Turned Pretty” features a shocking twist.

The show's eighth episode follows its main character, Belly (Lola Tung), as she prepares to walk down the aisle and marry her childhood best friend Jeremiah (Gavin Casalegno). However, a surprising revelation means the day doesn't go to plan.
The couple decides not to say "I do" after Jeremiah accuses Belly of still being in love with his brother, Conrad (Christopher Briney).

Jeremiah’s change of heart is also largely due to a letter his mom, Susannah, who died several years before, wrote for him to read on his wedding day. While the letter was in an envelope addressed to Jeremiah, it is revealed during the episode that Susannah accidentally switched the letters. (Eagle-eyed viewers have spotted a moment from Season 2 in which a very sick Susannah, played by Rachel Blanchard, drops the letters she was writing, and Laurel, played by Jackie Chung, helps hastily stuff them back into their envelopes.)
So the letter Jeremiah reads in the episode was actually meant for Conrad.

While only visible for a couple of seconds on screen, the letter is integral in Jeremiah’s decision to break off the engagement. So, what does Susannah's message say? And why does he decide not to marry Belly?
What Does Susannah’s Letter Say to Conrad?

The letter was not read aloud during the episode, but the handwritten note is shown in full for a few seconds on screen. While some viewers paused the show to read its contents, the show’s creator Jenny Han acknowledged on Instagram, "I know some of y’all can’t read cursive."
Han shared the letter’s full text on Instagram Aug. 28, the day after the episode’s release.
Dear Conrad,
I can hardly believe my little bug is getting married today! I am just bursting at the thought that my beautiful boy has found the person he wants to spend the rest of his life with.

I only ever got to see you in love once, and for that I will always, always be grateful. Not just that I got to see you in love but I got to see you be loved. Oh, the way she looked at you — it was like you were the only boy in the world. As a mother, there is no greater gift than to see her child be so dearly loved by another person. Today, if there is even a fraction of the love I saw then, I am more than happy. I am overjoyed.

Don’t be afraid to tell her every day how very much she means to you. Cook for her, be a good listener, don’t try to win every argument. Jewelry is always welcome. Pay attention to if she wears gold or silver. If she’s not a jewelry girl, then chocolate.
Loving you always and forever,
Mom
What Happens with Susannah's Letter in the Books?
In the books the show is based on, also written by Han, Susannah’s full letter to Conrad is never revealed.
However, the scene in the show where Jeremiah reads the letter is   similar to the book. Like in the show, Conrad brings the letter to Jeremiah after he disappears on the morning of the wedding day.

“Swallowing, he tore the envelope open,” Conrad narrates in the trilogy's third book, "We'll Always Have Summer." “I watched him as he read, hoping, knowing, my mom would have the right words. She always knew what to say to Jeremiah. Jere started to cry as he read, and I turned my head away.”

After reading the letter, Jeremiah reveals that the letter was meant for Conrad. Upset by its contents, Jeremiah tells Conrad that he is not his brother anymore and leaves. Conrad then opens the letter and sees the “Dear Conrad” at the top. He starts to cry, and the chapter ends.
Later in the book, when Jeremiah ends the engagement with Belly, he tells her what the letter said.
“My mom must have mixed up the envelopes,” Jeremiah tells Belly. “In the letter she said — she said she only ever got to see him in love once. That was with you.”
Jeremiah decides not to get married because he doesn’t want to hold Belly back from Conrad, saying that she will never move on if he does.
The book ends after that reveal, followed by a three-page epilogue.

But the final scene of Episode 8 ends on a different note than its source material. After calling off the wedding, Belly heads to an airport and buys a ticket to Paris. While in line to board the plane, as Taylor Swift's "Cardigan" plays in the background, she sees Conrad. The screen fades to black and the credits roll before Conrad spots Belly, leaving fans on a slight cliffhanger before Episode 9 drops Sept. 3.
With three episodes left to go, fans wonder how the remainder of the season will diverge from the books.
"we are in uncharted territory. 3 episodes to go and very very little book left," one viewer said on X. "we should all be terrified."

title: ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ Voice Actors on the Surreal Moment BTS Became Fans
summary: The voice actors of “KPop Demon Hunters” reveal how BTS' recognition of the movie and its music felt like a dream.
story: Voice actors May Hong, Arden Cho and Ji-young Yoo couldn’t contain their excitement as K-pop idols became fans of their newest project, “KPop Demon Hunters.”

The film — now Netflix’s most-watched movie with 236 million views — follows the girl group HUNTR/X on a demon-slaying mission to protect the world by sealing the Honmoon, a portal between the human and demon realms.
Hong voices Mira, Cho voices Rumi, and Yoo voices Zoey — together, they make up the girl group.
In an interview with The Hollywood Reporter, Yoo, who is a “really big BTS fan,” says she was left in shock when BTS started to sing songs from the film on their livestreams.
Cho, who was in Korea shortly after the film’s release, says she saw “the response and the love from actual idols who are living this life,” calling the moment “incredible” and a “stamp of approval.”
While attending her first convention, Hong said that seeing the line of fans waiting to meet her was “absurd,” thinking that the film was not as big as she thought.
Other BTS members have sung along to many of the film's soundtracks in other livestreams, leaving many fans in shock that their idols are also watching the film.
“It just felt like my body and my brain separated and I still can’t really talk about it. I think once that happened, I went like, ‘oh my God!’” Yoo said in utter shock.
“When we were starting to get recognition from actual K-pop idols, that’s when we’ve done something right,” she added.

When asked for their take on a live action remake of the film, Hong believed that Sailor Jupiter from Sailor Moon would best portray Mira, whereas Yoo believed Chu from Luna would be a good fit for Zoey.
However, singers like Beyoncé, Kelly Clarkson, BLACKPINK, TWICE and NewJeans were the people who the trio believed could seal the Honmoon.
“And of course, BTS,” Cho said with a laugh.

title: How Much Did Taylor Swift's Engagement Ring Cost? 6 Jewelers Share Their Guesses
summary: Jewelers estimate that the ring Travis Kelce used to propose to Taylor Swift could cost anywhere from $400,000 to 1.2 million dollars.
story: Fans are analyzing every detail from Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce's engagement, and the new ring on the star's left hand is no exception.
Observers have examined the close-up image of the diamond featured in slide three of the pair’s engagement announcement to guess the cut and price.
Based on the picture, what can we learn about the singer’s new stone? Here’s what experts have to say.
What kind of diamond does Taylor Swift have?
The gemstone in Swift’s ring is an old-mine diamond in an elongated cushion cut, experts tell TODAY.com.

“Taylor Swift’s engagement ring is seriously gorgeous and one of a kind,” Megan Kothari, founder of fine jewelry brand AARYAH, tells TODAY.com. “It is probably a natural, elongated antique cushion-cut diamond of around eight to 10 carats.”
The cut of Swift’s ring is “really rare and hard to come by,” Kothari continues.

Old-mine diamonds are antiques dating back to the time the stones were hand-cut and polished. Jeweler Hannah Florman tells TODAY.com that the style can “send a signal that the wearer values individuality over mass-produced perfection."
The ring was designed by Kindred Lubeck of Artifex Fine Jewelry, TODAY.com can confirm.
Kothari says that the ring is set in yellow gold and appears to feature some delicate hand engraving. It also could have smaller “pave” diamonds around the band, Kothari adds.
How much does the ring cost?
Due to several unknown details surrounding Swift's ring, experts have a wide range of opinions on how much the ring is worth.
“It’s always too hard to say unless you get the designer to disclose the price,” jeweler Matt Harris tells TODAY.com

"We’d need to know the color and clarity which can’t be determined from a photo," Harris continues. "And then of course, there’s the price you pay for the designer. Some designers charge more than others.”
Harris estimates that the ring totals around $120,000 on the low end, but could cost as much as $500,000, depending on a variety of factors.
“There are very few diamonds with this age, shape and cut on the worldwide market,” Harris adds. “It’s truly a unique stone, and that’s definitely worth something.”
Rachel Enright, diamond and gem specialist at CustomMade Jewelers, says the ring, which she guesses is around eight carats, could be even more expensive than Harris estimates.
“Assuming it’s a natural diamond, D color grade and internally flawless clarity, the diamond alone would cost somewhere around $935,000,” Enright tells TODAY.com.
Simone Kendle, CEO of Wove Made Inc., which designed Swift's viral TNT bracelet, agrees that the center stone of the ring likely ranges from seven to eight carats and pushes $1 million in value.
“A diamond of that size and character would be valued in the millions, depending on its color and clarity,” Kendle says. “It’s truly one of a kind.”

Austin Willard, founder and CEO of Faithful Platform Fine Jewelry and Engagement Rings, notes that “the clarity, cut, and color characteristics of this stone will be the major driving point of price.”
Because these specifics remain unknown, the cost of the ring could range from $400,000 to $1.2 million, Willard estimates.
Diamond dealer David Steinmetz estimates the ring could be about $800,000.
Laura Taylor of Laurel Diamonds says if the diamond is of excellent quality, a ring like this could be between $675,000 to $1 million.

Regardless of how much the ring cost, some fans still couldn’t be more excited to see the duo find the happy ending to their story and link the big news back to Swift's search for love throughout her career.
“I like shiny things, but I’d marry you with paper rings,” Swift sings in her “Lover” song “Paper Rings.”
Kelce didn’t propose to Swift with paper rings, but he still delivered a one-of-a-kind ring worthy of a pop star proposal.

title: Selena Gomez Used a 2009 Throwback to Celebrate Taylor Swift’s Engagement
summary: Singer Selena Gomez celebrated Taylor Swift on Instagram after she and Travis Kelce announced their engagement — and she added a little throwback twist.
story: Selena Gomez marked Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce’s engagement, adding a nostalgic nod to their longtime friendship.
Gomez took to Instagram on Aug. 27 to celebrate the newly engaged couple by reposting the original post shared by Swift and Kelce with Queen’s song, “You’re My Best Friend.”
“When bestie gets engaged,” Gomez wrote alongside the photo with a smiley face and hearts emoji.
Gomez also shared an X post Swift made on April 13, 2009 that was then reposted by another X user, highlighting the two singers’ relationship statuses present-day.
“@selenagomez Real love still happens sometimes,” Swift wrote in her original post from 2009. “It’s not just something we make up when we’re nine. I have to believe that. You do too,” she added.
An X user later shared a side-by-side photo of Gomez and her fiancé Benny Blanco and a photo of Swift and Kelce, from their original engagement announcements.
“16 years later,” the X post read as Gomez posted the screenshot on her stories with a holding back tears emoji.
Gomez and Swift’s 16-year friendship dates to their first interaction when they met through their exes Joe and Nick Jonas in 2008. At the time, Gomez was 15 and Swift was 18.
On internet influencer Jake Shane’s podcast “Therapuss,” Gomez shared the insider details on the beginnings of their friendship.
“She and I like to say that the best thing we got out of those relationships was each other because it was really sweet,” Gomez shared.
“So, at that age, we became best friends, bonded over the breakup as girls do and then we stuck around for all the ups and downs that came after and here we are now 16 years later,” she continued.
In 2009, Gomez also shared in an interview with Seventeen that Swift was her go-to person for love advice.
“If I ever have an issue, Taylor has gone through it, because she’s older than me, and she gives the most thought-out answers,” the singer said.
“And what I love about Taylor is that she does believe in the whole love story and Prince Charming and soulmates. Because of her, I haven’t lost faith.”

title: Why Is Cardi B in Court? The Rapper's Viral Testimony, Explained
summary: Why is Cardi B testifying in a trial? Explaining the rapper's viral testimony and what's going on.
story: Cardi B's latest performance that has fans buzzing has come on a witness stand.
The rapper has been appearing at a Los Angeles trial in which she's been accused by a former security guard of assaulting her in 2018.
Clips of her testimony have gone viral thanks to her facial reactions and blunt, expletive-laden answers to questions in cross examination.

Cardi B, 32, whose real name is Belcalis Marlenis Almánzar, has been accused of assault in a civil lawsuit filed by security guard Emani Ellis, who alleges the rapper physically attacked her in the hallway of a Beverly Hills obstetrician's office in 2018. Cardi B has denied the allegations.
Here's what to know about the case and Cardi B's court appearance.
Why Is Cardi B in Court?

In 2020, security guard Emani Ellis filed a civil lawsuit against Cardi B alleging assault and battery, intentional infliction of emotional distress, negligence and false imprisonment for an incident that occurred in 2018, according to court documents.

Ellis alleges in court documents that she was working as a security guard on the fifth floor of an obstetrician's office when she and Cardi B got into an altercation. She alleges that the rapper struck her in the head, face, and body, spit on her and used multiple racial slurs, according to court documents.

Ellis also alleges that Cardi B "used her celebrity status" to get Ellis fired and was involved in destroying video surveillance footage of the incident. Ellis has received "psychological and medical treatment as a result of this incident," according to the lawsuit.
Cardi B has denied the allegations.

The former security guard testified in court in Alhambra, Calif., on Aug. 25 that she was excited after seeing Cardi B get off an elevator at the obstetrician's office in February 2018, and said, "Wow, it's Cardi B."

Ellis testified the rapper then accused her of making public that Cardi B had been visiting the obstetrician's office. She said in her testimony that Cardi B had turned to her and said, "Why the f— are you telling people you’ve seen me?" according to The Los Angeles Times.
Ellis alleged in court that Cardi B then struck her repeatedly, spit on her and called her racial slurs.

The rapper was four months pregnant with her first child with rapper Offset at the time of the alleged incident. She was going to a medical appointment related to her pregnancy with her daughter Kulture, who is now 7 years old, but she had not publicly revealed she was pregnant yet.
What Did Cardi B Say on the Witness Stand?
The rapper's testimony on Aug. 27 went viral as she scrunched her face and looked to the judge after some of the questions and gave blunt answers to others.
She also has changed up her look for each court appearance, one day wearing a blonde wig and the next day a black one.
Cardi B testified that when she got off the elevator at the doctor's office, Ellis was recording her with her phone, which made Cardi B defensive.
Ron Rosen Janfaza, the attorney for Ellis, asked her what Cardi B said to Ellis during the confrontation.
"I said, 'Bitch get f--- out my face, why are you in my face?'" Cardi B said on the stand. "Why are you recording me? Ain't you supposed to be security?"
Janfanza then asked her to repeat it, resulting in Cardi B scrunching up her face in incredulity before the judge told him to move on.
"Cardi B in court today was like an SNL skit," one fan wrote on X of the moment.
"Oh Cardi B was not having it in her court trial today, the lawyer was getting aggressive and she was returning the same energy," another person wrote on X.
Janfanza followed by asking if Cardi B was disabled at the time of the incident.
"When you're pregnant I'm very disabled. You want me to tell you things I can't do?" she said to laughter in the courtroom.
Cardi B said at the time she couldn't protect herself "even if I wanted to" and that Ellis "is like twice my size."

She also said during her testimony that she never put her hands on Ellis, who alleges in her lawsuit that Cardi B scratched her face with one of her nails. Cardi B said the two got chest to chest, but the fight was only verbal.
"She couldn’t get a scratch from me because I didn’t touch her,” she said.
Janfanza asked if she was angry.
“Yes I was angry! Because I’m pregnant!” she said. “And this girl’s about to beat my ass!”
The rapper also previously testified on Aug. 26 that she did not spit on Ellis or call her any racial slurs.
The trial is off the rest of the week and is expected to resume after Sept. 1, according to The Associated Press.

title: Bill Belichick's Girlfriend, Jordon Hudson, Files Trademark for 'Gold Digger' Accessories
summary: An attorney for TCE Rights Management, a company managed by Bill Belichick’s girlfriend, Jordon Hudson, has filed a trademark application for "gold digger."
story: The term "gold digger" could be a new trademarked word.

An attorney for TCE Rights Management, a company managed by Bill Belichick’s girlfriend, Jordon Hudson, has filed a trademark application for the popular term, according to documents reviewed by TODAY.com.

The application, which was filed on Aug. 25, states that TCE Rights Management plans on using the term — which refers to a person who forms a romantic relationship with another in pursuit of monetary or material gain — for goods and services like jewelry or key chains.

In addition to gold digger, TCE Rights Management is also looking to trademark words like "The Belichick Way," "Chapel Bill" and "Ignore the Noise (Bill's Version)" for clothing, audio and video streaming, keychains and printed material.

The new business move comes amid criticism that the former New England Patriots coach and his girlfriend have received in recent months. At the 2025 ESPY Awards, comedian Shane Gillis made a joke about the couple's 49-year age gap.
“A bookie is what Bill Belichick reads to his girlfriend before bedtime," he said in his opening monologue to a laughing crowd.
Gillis then joked about some of the books the pair would read like, “Very Horny Caterpillar," "The Little Engine That Could But Needed a Pill First,” and “Goodnight Boobs.”
Though, despite all of his jokes, he said he is a fan of men dating younger women.

“Also, I’m not trashing Bill Belichick,” he said. “First off, he’s 73-years-old and he’s dating a hot 24-year-old and people are criticizing him? What happened to this country? We used to be a great country.”

In an April interview with “CBS Sunday Morning," Belichick revealed how he deals with people “invested” in his relationship with Hudson and said he's "never been too worried about what everybody else thinks."
“Just try to do what I feel like is best for me and what’s right," he said.

title: U.S. blocks Palestinian leaders from attending U.N. meeting in New York
summary: Members of Mahmoud Abbas' Palestinian government will be unable to travel to the United Nations General Assembly after Marco Rubio revoked their visas.
story: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is barring Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas from attending the meeting of world leaders at the United Nations General Assembly in New York next month where several countries including France, Canada and the U.K. are expected to formally recognize a Palestinian state.

Abbas, along with approximately 80 other officials from his Palestinian Authority (PA), had their U.S. visas revoked or denied ahead of the meeting according to a State Department official, who accused them of undermining the prospects for peace in Gaza where Israel escalated its assault on Friday.

Both the PA and and the umbrella Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) “must repudiate terrorism,” before “they can be taken seriously as partners for peace,” State Department spokesperson Tommy Pigott said Saturday, adding that they   should abandon “the pursuit of unilateral recognition of statehood.” The Trump administration “does not reward terrorism,” he said.

As the host country for the United Nations, the U.S. is required under a 1947 “headquarters agreement,” to grant foreign diplomats access to the U.N. but exceptions have been made by past administrations for both security and policy reasons.
After the U.S. refused to issue a visa to PLO leader Yasser Arafat in 1988, The U.N. General Assembly held a meeting that year in Geneva instead of New York so he could address it.

Headed by Abbas, who has not faced an election in almost two decades, the Palestinian Authority administers parts of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. It has not governed in Gaza since 2007 when the Palestinian president's security forces were driven out by the Islamic militant group Hamas.
In June, Abbas wrote a letter to France’s president in which he condemned the Hamas attack and called on hostages taken by the militant group to be released.

Pigott's comments echoed a statement from the State Department on Friday which said the PA and the PLO “must consistently repudiate terrorism,” including the Hamas-led terror attacks on Oct. 7, 2023, which saw 1,200 people killed and around 250 people taken hostage.
It also accused PA and PLO of contributing to “Hamas’s refusal to release its hostages, and to the breakdown of the Gaza ceasefire talks.”
Washington has said it can deny visas for security, extremism and foreign policy reasons. Israel’s Foreign Minister Gideon Saar welcomed the State Department’s decision.

But Riyad Mansour, the Palestinian ambassador to the U.N. told reporters Friday that as far as he knew, “the head of our delegation is President Mahmoud Abbas, and he is coming to represent the state of Palestine and the Palestinian people in that conference.”
On the visa revocations, he added, “We will see exactly what it means and how it applies to any of our delegation, and we will respond accordingly.”

Several European foreign ministers criticized the decision ahead of a meeting in Copenhagen, Denmark on Saturday. A U.N. General Assembly “cannot be subject to any restrictions on access,” French Foreign Minister Jean-Noel Barrot told reporters.

France, the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia are each expected to formally recognize a Palestinian state at the assembly, a move the Trump administration has opposed. The state of Palestine is currently recognized by 147 of the U.N.’s 193 member states.

title: Dominican Republic's total abortion ban has cost women's lives, campaigners warn
summary: Artists and activists are telling the stories of women and mothers who've died from high-risk pregnancies, and push for changes to the recently passed penal code that keeps the ban in place.
story: With a birthday cake in hand, well-known Dominican Republic comedian Carlos Sánchez recounted in an Instagram post how 25-year-old Winifer Núñez Beato died in 2021 after doctors on the island refused to end her high-risk pregnancy because of the country’s total abortion ban.

Núñez Beato left behind a husband and a young daughter. In the video, Sánchez said the cake is not for his birthday, but rather to mark another year where he’s asking for women not to die because of a law that stops doctors from saving their lives.

Sánchez told NBC News he felt compelled to use his platform to raise awareness because “it’s a barbarity that in this day and age a mother has to put her life at risk over a risky pregnancy that could be ended but the law prohibits doctors to do so.”

Sánchez is among many artists and activists in the Dominican Republic taking part in a social media campaign to push for amending a recently passed penal code that maintains a complete ban on abortion. Many artists have used their platforms to tell the stories of Dominican women who have lost their lives to pregnancy-related conditions.

On Instagram, singer and actress Techy Fatule tells the story of Damaris Mejia, who went to three different hospitals when she started feeling ill and had a high fever. According to Fatule, medical personnel didn’t know what to do with Mejia’s high-risk pregnancy. She was sent home with painkillers and died that night. Fatule says doctors couldn’t save her because of the ban, and ends with words, “Life is full of exceptions.”

The Dominican Republic is a conservative country that features the Bible on its flag. The country signed a concordat, or agreement, with the Vatican in 1954 making Catholicism the state religion, though the constitution allows freedom of worship.

The country’s Catholic Church backs the abortion ban, as well as evangelical groups. But Alianza Cristiana Dominicana, a group formed in 2017 by women of different Christian denominations, is pushing for the penal code to include what are known in the region as the “tres causales,” or three causes or circumstances where ending pregnancies should be allowed: when the woman’s life is at risk, in the case of rape or incest, and when fetal malformations are incompatible with life. The “tres causales” are used in other countries throughout Latin America that have eased total bans on abortion.
Alianza Cristiana Dominicana has partnered with the artists to share the stories.

So far this year, there have been 100 documented maternal deaths in the Dominican Republic. Natalia Mármol, of the Coalition for Women’s Lives and Rights, believes those lives could have been saved if abortions were legal.

“This is a fight to guarantee minimum protection for life, health and dignity for girls and women,” said Mármol. “We are asking for minimal protections, so women don’t die on a hospital bed. So a 13- or 15-year-old girl is not obliged to continue with a pregnancy that is the product of a rape. And so a woman can decide when a pregnancy is not viable.”

The Dominican Republic’s previous penal code had been in place since 1884, and efforts to reform it failed for decades. The new penal code was approved by legislators and signed into law by President Luis Abinader.
Abinader had previously expressed support for making exceptions to the abortion ban, but after winning re-election he didn’t push for changes.

After the vote, Abinader said the penal code, which covers many types of crime, “is not the ideal but it’s the best possible, since among other things, it substitutes legislation that dates back to 1884.”

Mármol said the new penal code does include points that the group advocated for, like the classification of femicide, the intentional killing of a woman or girl, as well as an increase in the severity of punishment for sexual assault.
She said the new penal code does not go into effect until August 2026 and there is time to tweak the law to include the three exceptions.

The Coalition for the Life and Rights of Women and other groups have pushed for years to have the three exceptions included, even erecting a camp in 2021 in front of the National Palace to pressure parliament.
In the Dominican Republic, women face up to two years in prison for having an abortion and doctors and midwives can receive five to 20 years for terminating a pregnancy.

Four other countries in Latin America and the Caribbean maintain a total prohibition on abortion, including Haiti, Nicaragua and El Salvador. Most of Latin America and the Caribbean allows abortion in limited cases.

Caribbean-pop singer and songwriter Isabel de Dios said she has been active in the feminist movement throughout her adulthood, often taking part in protests. Her first song, called “Colonizado,” or “Colonized,” talks about how society expects people to stay within established roles and turns a blind eye to many situations.
She called the penal code “crazy,” “dictatorial” and “feudal.”
“What kind of society are we constructing?” she said.

title: Yemen's Houthis say Israeli airstrike killed prime minister of rebel-controlled government
summary: An Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of Yemen’s rebel-controlled government, the Iran-backed Houthi militant group said Saturday
story: An Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of Yemen’s rebel-controlled government, the Iran-backed Houthi militant group said Saturday.
Ahmed al-Rawahi was killed Thursday alongside other ministers in a strike on the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, the rebels said in a statement.
“We declare the martyrdom of the fighter Ahmed Ghalib Al-Rahawi, Prime Minister in the Government of Change and Construction, along with a number of his fellow ministers,” it said.

Al-Rahawi, who had served as prime minister of the Houthi-led government since 2024, was killed during a government workshop evaluating “its activities and performance during a year of its work,” the statement added.
Following his death, Houthi President Mahdi Al-Mashat appointed Mohammed Ahmed Ahmed Muftah, the first deputy prime minister, to serve as acting prime minister.
The Israeli military said Thursday it “precisely struck a Houthi terrorist regime military target in the area of Sanaa in Yemen.”
The Houthis have repeatedly fired missiles at Israel during its war with Hamas, framing their attacks on Israel and Red Sea shipping as part of an allied defense of Palestinians in Gaza.
In response to Houthi attacks, Israel has bombarded rebel-held areas in Yemen.

title: NBC News analysis finds that Israel hit Gaza hospital four times
summary: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military struck Nasser Hospital at least four times during its morning attack on southern Gaza that killed 22 people earlier this week, according to an NBC News analysis of newly obtained video
story: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military struck Nasser Hospital at least four times during its morning attack on southern Gaza that killed 22 people earlier this week, according to an NBC News analysis of newly obtained video.

The findings come as Reuters — whose cameraman Hussam al-Masri was among five journalists killed Monday in the Israeli strikes — said the Israeli military was “fully aware” that its team and other journalists were operating from the hospital in southern Gaza.

The agency told NBC News on Wednesday that it had offered daily live feeds to its news clients from that location in recent weeks, but earlier in the war had stopped sharing its teams' exact locations “after so many journalists were killed in IDF strikes.”
What initially appeared to be a “double tap” strike — a tactic in which a target is hit, then struck again often after first responders have rushed in — was in fact more extensive.

Al-Masri’s live feed freezes at 10:08 a.m. local time but there’s no video of the first strikes. Video of the aftermath of these hits shows smoke billowing from two separate staircases: the one where journalists were working and a second, around the corner next to the intensive care unit.
Al-Masri was killed in the first strike.

Minutes later, at 10:17 a.m., after journalists and first responders arrived on the staircase used by journalists — including men carrying a gurney seen on video wearing clearly identifiable high visibility vests — a second strike hits.

Video obtained and verified by NBC News shows two additional projectiles striking the fourth-floor staircase within milliseconds of each other. Plumes of smoke can be seen rising from all affected areas.

N.R. Jenzen-Jones, director of the arms intelligence firm Armament Research Services, said video of the incident after the first strike pointed to a direct-fire weapon, with damage “consistent with that expected from a multi-purpose tank gun projectile.”

Video of the second strike also appeared to show two projectiles, he said. Their flight pattern and “bright emission… more likely to be from a tracer” suggested they came from tank rounds, Jenzen-Jones said. The timing, he added, implies “two tanks may have fired on the target simultaneously.”

The Israel Defense Forces did not respond to a request for comment on the newest revelations. The IDF has not provided NBC News with any additional information since it released preliminary findings on Tuesday.

In its initial inquiry, the IDF said troops had identified a camera at the hospital “positioned by Hamas” that was being used to observe its activity. It added that “troops operated to remove the threat by striking and dismantling the camera.”
But according to multiple eyewitnesses on the ground, including journalists and doctors at the hospital, there was only one camera positioned on the roof of the hospital: al-Masri’s Reuters camera.
Reuters said Thursday that “Israel was fully aware that Reuters and multiple other news organizations were operating from Nasser Hospital."
Journalist Ibrahim Qanan, who was reporting live on Alghad TV at the time of the second strike, told NBC News that “Reuters and AP have a specific location, the highest location.”
Mohammed Saqer, director of nursing at Nasser Hospital, said Wednesday that the Israeli military “could have called us” if it had any trouble, saying the “the IDF knows our numbers.”
“We simply could have just removed the camera,” he said.
Hours after the attack, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel “deeply regrets the tragic mishap.”

The Israeli military, which did not provide evidence to substantiate the claims that Hamas ran a camera on the roof of the hospital or address the multiple strikes on the facility, added that an investigation had been ordered into “several gaps,” including the “authorization process” before the attack.
Bassem Naim, a senior Hamas official, denied the group had any camera in the area.
Video of the aftermath showed smoke rising and damage at both staircases.

Dr. Osama Asfour, a member of the board of directors of Nasser Medical Complex, said the strike hit the area around the ICU, and operating rooms had so much damage the hospital was forced to halt surgeries for the day.

“The targeting of the northern side led to the disruption of the electric line, water and communications, causing destruction inside the surgery rooms and resulting in halted operations for a full day," Asfour said.
Molly Hunter reported from Jerusalem, and Matthew Mulligan and Freddie Clayton reported from London.

title: Reuters stopped sharing Gaza locations with Israel after many journalists killed in IDF strikes
summary: International news agency Reuters says that it stopped sharing the locations of its teams in the Gaza Strip with the Israeli military after “so many journalists were killed in IDF strikes.”
story: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces have killed so many journalists that Reuters has stopped sharing the locations of its teams in the Gaza Strip with the country's military, the international news agency told NBC News.
A Reuters cameraman who regularly operated its live position on the roof of Nasser Hospital was one of five journalists among 22 people killed in an Israeli attack on the facility Monday.

“In the early days of the conflict, Reuters, like other news outlets, shared the locations our teams would be using in an effort to ensure they would not be targeted by the [Israel Defense Forces],“ a spokesperson for the London-based news organization, one of the world’s largest, told NBC News late Wednesday.
That included sharing on “multiple occasions” that its journalists were operating out of Nasser Hospital, where the strikes were caught on video by the Arabic-language channel Al Ghad TV.

“We subsequently desisted from giving precise coordinates of our teams after so many journalists were killed in IDF strikes,” added Reuters, which said it ran a live feed from the site for the last 18 months.

In response to a request for comment on the Reuters statement, the IDF said it had “no further comment beyond the statement that has been put out.” Soon after the incident, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it had been a “tragic mishap.”

In a statement Tuesday, the IDF claimed that an initial inquiry found that troops had identified a camera at the hospital that was being used to observe its troops “in order to direct terrorist activities against them.” It added that “troops operated to remove the threat by striking and dismantling the camera.”
